arrayGenerator

Class SimpleRandomListingGenerator

  • java.lang.Object
    • arrayGenerator.SortedListingGenerator
      • arrayGenerator.RandomListingGenerator
        • arrayGenerator.SimpleRandomListingGenerator
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    SimpleRandomListingGeneratorTimer

    public class SimpleRandomListingGenerator
extends RandomListingGenerator
    Implements the randomise() method to complete RandomListingGenerator. This simple implementation does not use a very efficient method of randomisation.
    Version:
    September 2019
    Author:
    Hugh Osborne

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods

      protected void randomise()
      Randomise the array.

      • Methods inherited from class arrayGenerator.SortedListingGenerator

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

    • Method Detail

      • randomise

        protected void randomise()
        Randomise the array. The algorithm is:
        • Access the sorted array
        • Create a new array of the same size (this will be the randomised array)
        • For each entry in the new array
          • Select a random, unused element of the sorted array
          • Enter it into the new array
          • Note that this entry in the sorted array has now been used
        • Once all the entries in the sorted array have been entered, in a random order, in the new array, copy the randomised array back to the Listing's main array
        The use of entries from the sorted array is managed by creating a third array, this time of booleans, of the same size as the sorted array. All values in this array are initialised to false (no entries have yet been used). Each time an entry in the sorted array is used, the corresponding boolean is set to true. We can then check whether an entry has been used by checking whether its corresponding boolean is true.
        Specified by:
        randomise in class RandomListingGenerator
